channel.title: BBC News - Middle East
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Israel extends Covid restrictions to three-year-olds as cases surge
item.description: Young children must show proof of a negative test to enter many indoor spaces, as infections surge.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani: Afghanistan's exiled president lands in UAE
item.description: The UAE says it has welcomed the president and his family on humanitarian grounds.

item.title: Israel battles huge wildfire near Jerusalem
item.description: The blaze has destroyed some 2,000 hectares (5,000 acres) of forest over the past three days.

item.title: Four Palestinians killed in clashes during Israeli raid
item.description: A firefight broke out during an undercover police operation in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Lebanon deadly petrol tank blast sparks protest at PM-designate's home
item.description: Protesters attack the PM-designate's home after 27 people are killed while queueing for fuel.

item.title: Polish law on property stolen by Nazis angers Israel
item.description: A new law will make it harder for people to recover property lost in World War Two.

item.title: Hamas rocket fire a war crime, Human Rights Watch says
item.description: The attacks, which killed 13 people in Israel in May, violated the laws of war, a probe finds.

item.title: UK and Russia ambassadors anger Iran by restaging WWII image
item.description: Iran condemns an "inappropriate" image of the UK and Russian ambassadors recreating a wartime image.

item.title: Wagner: Scale of Russian mercenary mission in Libya exposed
item.description: A Samsung tablet obtained by the BBC unveils chilling details of how mercenaries fought in Libya’s war.

item.title: Princess Latifa: Campaign to free Dubai ruler's daughter disbanded
item.description: The Dubai ruler's daughter was pictured in Iceland after accusing her father of keeping her captive.

item.title: How latte art led to a job from hell in Oman
item.description: A South African barista was offered a dream opportunity in Oman but unknowingly signed away his freedoms.

item.title: The murderous crime wave sweeping Israel's Arabs
item.description: Many killings often go unsolved, with blame being put on the police.

item.title: Tunisia crisis: Democrats, despots and the fight for power
item.description: Tunisia is in turmoil since the president suspended parliament and increased his own power.

item.title: West faces dilemmas over tanker attack
item.description: A drone attack on a ship off the coast of Oman has worsened already strained ties with Iran.

item.title: Iran water: What's causing the shortages?
item.description: Iranian officials have warned of historic drought while experts blame years of poor water management.

item.title: Gaza photographer hopes digital art boom can help raise aid money
item.description: A Palestinian photographer wants to help children by selling an image from May's conflict.

item.title: How US military pullback in Iraq could benefit Iran
item.description: The withdrawal of remaining US combat troops could help Iran achieve its ambitions.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Egypt's Sherif to 'play with heart' in historic medal bid
item.description: Mayar Sherif will play 'with her heart' as she becomes the first Egyptian woman to play Olympic tennis for her country.

item.title: Pegasus: Who are the alleged victims of spyware targeting?
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi's wife and the editor of the Financial Times are among those said to be targeted.

item.title: The referee making Olympic history
item.description: The first Arab and African woman to referee 3x3 basketball at the Olympics shares how her Muslim faith has guided her career.

item.title: Why is Israel demolishing homes in East Jerusalem?
item.description: Israel says the homes were built without planning permission and it is to try to keep East Jerusalem in order.

item.title: Beirut blast: ‘The day our city exploded’
item.description: One year on from the blast that rocked Beirut, no one has yet been made accountable.

item.title: Lebanon blast: ‘Path towards reform irreversible’
item.description: We owe it to our people to tackle issues which led to the blast, the ambassador to the UK says.

item.title: The separated refugees brought back together by judo
item.description: Sanda Aldass and Muna Dahouk have trained together since childhood but the war in Syria separated them.

item.title: Lebanon’s descent into darkness
item.description: The country's economic crisis has forced some families to move into refugee camps to survive.
